newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Bougainville rebels reject PNG mine buy-back.
newsitem.headline: Bougainville rebels reject PNG mine buy-back.

text.p: Secessionist rebels on Bougainville island warned the Papua New Guinea government on Monday that the island's giant copper mine would remain closed until a political solution was reached in their conflict.

"We closed the CRA mine in 1989 and it will remain so until a political agenda for the people of Bougainville is settled," said Moses Havini, Sydney-based spokesman for the Bougainville Interim Government, which represents the rebels.

Papua New Guinea Prime Minister Sir Julius Chan said on Sunday his government wanted to buy RTZ Corp Plc-CRA Ltd's controlling stake in the Panguna copper mine as part of a solution to the nine-year secessionist crisis on Bougainville.
He said the buy-back plan was part of a "radical initiative" to end the conflict, along with the recent hiring of African mercenaries as military advisers.
"The original claims and dispute regarding this mine are at the heart of the Bougainville crisis and (are) critical to a fair and lasting solution," Chan said in a statement.
Chan said the buy-back scheme would result in compensation and a reconstruction package for local landowners.
Landowners disgruntled over royalty payments from the mine in central Bougainville sabotaged the mine in the late 1980s, with their wave of violence evolving into a secessionist revolt.
The crisis on Bougainville flared last week when the Papua New Guinea government confirmed it had hired mercenaries as advisors for local troops on a mission against the rebels.
The use of mercenaries attracted criticism from Australia, New Zealand, Britain and the United States.

Havini said Bougainville Revolutionary Army rebels had rejected Chan's buy-back scheme. "Chan probably suffers from memory lapses. We have unsuccessfully tried to negotiate with the PNG government...for the last 25 years now," he said.
"Right throughout this period not once did the PNG government and CRA come to the negotiating table with us."
CRA on Monday said it had not been formally contacted about the buy-back scheme, but expected to be approached soon.
"CRA is obliged to consider any such approach on behalf of shareholders on its merits," the company said.

Shares in Bougainville Copper Ltd, which operated the Panguna mine for 17 years until its closure, surged five cents or almost nine percent to 61 Australian cents (US$0.48) early on Monday on news of the buy-back scheme. The mine produced 166,000 tonnes of copper-in-concentrate in 1988.
CRA, the Australian arm of Anglo-Australia dual listed mining giant RTZ-CRA, owns 53.6 percent of Bougainville Copper, with the PNG government holding 19.1 percent.
But mining analysts said any resumption of mining would be at least three to four years away and would rely entirely on a political solution to the Bougainville crisis.
"Rehabilitation would take quite a few years," said Peter O'Connor, mining analyst with Macquarie Equities. "CRA has conservatively estimated that at at least three to four years."
CRA has estimated it would cost some A$450 million (US$350 million) to restart the mine.
"The key risk is a political risk and at this stage CRA would be unlikely to even consider (reopening) it at this time," said O'Connor.
